definition.en: Potassium abundance measured by a spectral gamma-ray emission spectrometric method
A measure of the natural gamma-ray emission of a material, related to the radioelements K, Th and U and/or their daughter products.
The longitudinal (spin-lattice) relaxation time, the decay constant for the recovery of the z component of the nuclear spin magnetisation towards its thermal equilibrium value.
The decay characteristics of signals emitted in a polarising field by populations of certain atomic nuclei following removal of an external magnetic field.

The time it takes for the magnetic resonance signal to irreversibly decay to 37% (1/e) of its initial value after its generation by tipping the longitudinal magnetisation towards the magnetic transverse plane.

The FID (Free Induction Decay) is the transient NMR signal resulting from the stimulation of the nuclei at the Larmor frequency. The characteristic time constant for a FID signal decay is called T2* (T-two-star).
Thorium abundance measured by a spectral gamma-ray emission spectrometric method
Uranium abundance measured by a spectral gamma-ray emission spectrometric method
Porosity determined by acoustic logging as a function of the difference in acoustic travel time between interstitial fluids and the rock matrix
Porosity is the ratio of pore spaces to rock volume. May be determined as either total or apparent porosity.
Permeability measured with air
A measure of the ability of a fluid to flow through a material. Units are normally expressed as darcy or millidarcy, but can also be expressed as the SI unit m^2 or cm^2
Grain density calculated by an unknown method
"Density" as a generic description is the mass per unit volume of a material where a more accurate description, or the method of determination (e.g. dry bulk, wet bulk, grain ) is not given.
Apparent mass density determined by a vacuum bagging method

Apparent porosity is the ratio of interconnected void spaces only, is derived determining the fluid volume of interconnecting pores and dividing by the bulk volume. This may be performed by gravimetry using water or gas pycnometry.

Water in the pore space that does not flow under normal reservoir conditions. When used in connection with a nuclear magnetic resonance measurement, the term refers to all the water that is not free to move. This includes capillary-bound water and clay-bound water.
The amount of water contained in a geologic material such as soil, sediments, or rock.
Borehole internal diameter (caliper) associated with gamma-gamma density borehole tools, units in mm

Water that is not free to move due to capillary tension. When used to describe NMR results, capillary-bound water is defined as the water signal between certain cutoffs, typically above 3 ms and below 33 ms.

Chargeability is the ability of the Earth to hold a direct current (DC) charge, with decay time measured in milliseconds (ms). This is most commonly measured using time-domain induced polarization (IP) equipment.
Water that is not free to move due to being bound to clays. When used to describe NMR results, clay-bound water is defined as the water signal below a certain cutoff, typically 3 ms.

The difference of temperature between two measuring points. The temperature differs either in time and/or position. Differential temperature is expressed in Kelvin. No matter if the value is measured in Â°Celsius or in Fahrenheit. Therefore the values can be compared easily. The units are expressed in Kelvin(K) The lowest temperature is 0 K. No negative numbers exist in the Kelvin scale.
The temperature of bore hole wall rocks as measure using a bore hole temperature probe

Density porosity is determined by emission of gamma-rays into the borehole wall and measurement of their interaction. Density porosity is then derived using other data to inform on the rock matrix density

en: particle density on a dry basis

definition.en: Ratio of the dry rock mass to the total volumes of the rock material and pores (ie, the bulk volume of the sample).
Dynamic Bulk Modulus calculated from laboratory measured ultrasonic properties
Dynamic Poisson's Ratio calculated from laboratory measured ultrasonic properties
Poisson's Ratio
Dynamic Shear Modulus
Dynamic Young's Modulus calculated from laboratory measured ultrasonic properties
Young's Modulus
The ability of a rock mass to conduct an electrical current, determined by electromagnetic induction

The spontaneous potential probe measures the differences in natural electrical potential between the surface electrode and an electrode in the drillhole, and so measures the differences in natural electrical potential between the drillhole fluid and the surrounding rock material. The spontaneous potential log is used to determine bed thicknesses, the nature of the formations, identify porous and permeable beds and indicate the salinity of the groundwater in the formation.
resistance between two points, measuring resistivity of different lithological units
The ability of a rock volume to impede an electrical current

Water that is mobile, available to flow, and not bound to surfaces of grains or minerals in rock. When used in connection with nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements, free water is all the water that is not clay bound, capillary bound or in mineral hydrates.
Incremental change in bulk density measured by a bore hole gamma density tool
Bulk density (combined minerals and pore fluids) derived using a bore hole gamma bulk density tool
Bulk density determined by a bore hole long spaced gamma density tool
Bulk density determined by a bore hole short-spaced gamma density tool. Also referred to as high resolution density.
Gas Permeability measure of ultra low permeability samples that are below limit of detection for standard poroperm tests
The density of a rock or mineral with no porosity, also known as matrix density, commonly in units of g/cm3.
The rate at which a rock mass conducts heat
Calculated heat production of a rock derived from its K, Th and U radioisotopic composition, density and age
The capacity of a rock to transmit water
Indirect tensile strength

The Koenigsberger ratio (Q ratio) is defined as the ratio in a rock of remanent magnetization to the induced magnetization in the Earth's field. Q = NRM (in A/m) / (K (in SI) * H (in A/m), where K is the magnetic susceptibility in SI units and H is the local geomagnetic field (generally based on the International Geomagnetic Reference Field value at the sample site and at the sampling date).
The degree to which a material can be magnetized in an external magnetic field, measured a dimensionless proportionality constant.
The geometric mean of the T2 NMR distribution. T2 is the transverse (or spin-spin) relaxation time.

Neutron porosity is determined by measuring the ability of wall rocks to slow fast neutrons to the slow thermal neutron state. The number of thermal neutrons created is proportional to the amount of hydrogen present, in the form of oil or water, in pore

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Porosity is determined by  measuring the relaxation of hydrogen nuclei after alignment by the strong magnetic field generated by the NMR tool. Values may include Effective Porosity (MPHI), Total Porosity (MSIG) and Clay-Bound Water Porosity (MCBW), normally quoted as MSIG

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Porosity is determined by  measuring the relaxation of hydrogen nuclei after alignment by the strong magnetic field generated by the NMR tool. Values may include Effective Porosity (MPHI), Total Porosity (MSIG) and Clay-Bound Water Porosity (MCBW), normally quoted as MSIG

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Porosity is determined by  measuring the relaxation of hydrogen nuclei after alignment by the strong magnetic field generated by the NMR tool. Values may include Effective Porosity (MPHI), Total Porosity (MSIG) and Clay-Bound Water Porosity (MCBW), normally quoted as MSIG
P-wave velocity of a rock core measured parallel to the core axis
Generic velocity of sound in rock, P- or S-wave unknown
P-Wave slowness measured at a single stress point during Unconfined Compressive Strength testing
P-Wave velocity measured at a single stress point during Unconfined Compressive Strength testing
Klinkenberg correction is applied to reduce air permeability to an equivalent liquid permeability
Remanent magnetisation (here assumed to be the natural remanent magnetisation) is the permanent magnetisation of a rock material, attained over the material's lifetime.
First arrival S-wave velocity measured parallel to core axis
S-Wave slowness measured at a single stress point during Unconfined Compressive Strength testing
S-Wave velocity measured at a single stress point during Unconfined Compressive Strength testing
P-wave velocity measured perpendicular to the core axis (radial), parallel to foliation strike
First arrival S-wave velocity measured perpendicular to core axis (radial), parallel to foliation strike
P-wave velocity, measured perpendicular to core axis (radial), perpendicular to foliation strike
First arrival S-wave velocity, measured perpendicular to core axis (radial), perpendicular to foliation strike
The directional dependance of heat flow in a rock mass
A material's ability to conduct heat
Porosity determined by automated optical scanning or point-counting methods on thin-sectioned material

Total porosity is the ratio of sealed-off and interconnected pores to rock volume, is derived from the excess of the bulk volume over grain volume as part of Archimedes density determinations. This may be performed by gravimetry using water or gas pycnometry.
Unconfined compressive strength
The saturated density of a sample. The saturating fluid may be water (determine density by gravimetry in water) or a gas (determine density by gas pycnometry).
Rock bulk density as measured by XCT scanner
Computed (X-ray) tomography porosity is derived in the laboratory using X-ray tomography (XCT) to measure mineral grains, saturated and unsaturated pore spaces in undisturbed samples
